content: How can I help you today?

I've been feeling really overwhelmed lately. My wife and I are having issues at home, my son has been acting out, and I feel like I just can't fix any of it. It's affecting everything—my work, my mood, my ability to focus—and honestly, I'm not sure what to do anymore.

It sounds like there's a lot weighing on you right now, with challenges in your family and how that's spilling over into other parts of your life. Feeling overwhelmed and unsure of what to do in these moments can be very difficult. What do you think would help you feel a little lighter in all of this?
I'm not really sure, to be honest. I just wish I knew how to fix everything—my son's behavior, my relationship with my wife, all of it. It's hard to even figure out where to start.

It sounds like you care deeply about your family and want things to improve, but you're feeling stuck trying to figure out where to begin. That can feel pretty overwhelming, especially when you’re trying to hold everything together on top of work and other responsibilities. What has helped you in the past when dealing with challenges like this?

To be honest, I don't know that I've dealt with anything this hard before. I usually just keep things to myself and try to push through, but this is so much bigger than me, and it feels like it's too much to handle on my own. I don't know how to move forward.

It sounds like you've been carrying a lot on your own, and now it’s reached a point where it feels too heavy to manage alone. That’s a tough place to be, but recognizing that it's bigger than you and that you may need support is an important step. What kind of support do you think might make a difference for you right now?

I'm not even sure what kind of support I need. My wife thinks this—talking to a therapist—might help, but I guess I don’t really know yet. Maybe I just need someone to tell me what to do because I feel like I’m doing everything wrong.

It's understandable to feel unsure about what kind of support you need right now, especially when it feels like everything is piling up. It’s clear you’re really trying, but it can be exhausting to feel like you're not getting anywhere. Talking can sometimes help to untangle those feelings and figure out the next steps. What do you feel would be the most important thing to focus on right now, whether it’s your family, your work, or even just your own sense of balance?

It's all important. I mean, I want to focus on my son first because he’s clearly hurting and acting out, but at the same time, my wife and I are struggling, and I feel disconnected from my daughter. And on top of that, I’m falling behind at work. It’s hard to say what to prioritize when everything feels like it’s falling apart at once.

It sounds like you're under a lot of pressure, with so many important relationships and responsibilities pulling at you from different directions. You care so much about your family and your work, but feeling like everything is falling apart can make it hard to even know where to begin. If you could take just one small step right now—just a starting point—what would that be?

Honestly, I have no idea. Maybe just figuring out how to help my son? If his behavior improves, maybe things with my wife will feel less tense, and I can focus on my daughter and work again. But I don’t even know how to help him. I’ve already tried everything I can think of, and nothing seems to work.

Wanting to focus on helping your son shows how deeply you care about him and your family. It’s frustrating when you’ve tried everything you can think of and still feel stuck. Maybe taking a moment to reflect—on what might be driving his behavior or what’s been happening for him recently—could give you some clues. Would you like to explore that together?

Even if you're unsure how to help him right now, it's clear how much you care about him. Sometimes, figuring out what’s behind his behavior can be a good place to start. Do you think there could be something specific he’s struggling with or that’s changed for him?

Yeah, I think he’s having a tough time with school and making friends. He’s always been sensitive, but lately, he’s been angry more than anything else. I’ve tried talking to him, but he just shuts down or lashes out. I feel so helpless. I want to be there for him, but I don’t know what he needs.

It sounds like he's going through a lot emotionally, and it’s hard for you to see him struggling and not know how to reach him. It’s understandable to feel helpless when he shuts down, especially when you’re trying so hard to help. Do you think there’s a way to create more calm moments with him, or are there things you think he might feel comfortable talking about?

Maybe. He used to really enjoy drawing and building things, but lately, he hasn't been doing much of that either. I guess I could try doing some of those activities with him and see if it helps him open up a little. I’m not sure he’d go for it, but it’s worth a try.

That sounds like a great step to try—sometimes doing something together can help take the pressure off and make it easier for him to open up. Even if he doesn’t talk right away, just spending that time with him might help him feel more supported. Would it feel manageable to start there and see how it goes?
Yeah, I think I could do that. It’s something simple, and it might help us reconnect a little. Even if it doesn’t fix anything right away, it’ll be good to spend time with him.

That's a great mindset—you’re giving him the space and the opportunity to connect, which is such an important first step. It sounds like you're ready to take small but meaningful actions, and that in itself is a big deal. How does it feel to have a starting point like this?
It feels like something I can at least try. It doesn’t fix the bigger issues, but it's better than sitting here feeling stuck. I guess it gives me a little bit of hope.
